g.text: The IEA provides comprehensive analyses of global energy investments, estimated at about 1.8 trillion
, and expected to reach that level again in 2021 after a
. Energy investments represent about 8% of global GFCF
(Section 15.3.2.1). In the power sector, fossil fuel

compatible Sustainable Development Scenario (SDS) and Net Zero scenarios. The IEA observes

These estimates also result in fossil fuel investments remaining larger in aggregate than the total tracked
limate finance worldwide (Section 15.3.2.2). For oil and gas companies, which are amongst the world
largest corporations and sometimes government owned or backed, low
to represent less than 1% of capital expenditure
. As discussed in the remainder of this
G solutions requires a combination of conducive public
policies, attractive investment opportunities, as well as the availability of financing to finance such a
In terms of financing provided to fossil fuel investments, available analyses point
role played by commercial banks and export credit agencies. Commercial banks provide both direct
lending as well as underwriting services, the latter facilitating capital raising from investors in the form
nce. Available estimates indicate that lending and underwriting extended over
2019 by 35 of the world’s largest banks to 2,100 companies active across the fossil fuel life
credit agencies, which are owned or backed by their government, de
guarantees and insurances or, less often, loans. I
related official export credits, out of which close to
80% for the oil and gas, and over 20% for coal
related assets lock in future GHG emissions that may be inconsistent with
ing carbon budgets and, as discussed above, with emission pathways to reach the Paris
Agreement goals. This inconsistency exposes investors and asset owners to the risk of stranded assets,
which results from potential sharp strengthening climate public pol
icies, i.e. transition risk. As a result,
a growing number of investors and financiers are assessing climate
related risks with the aim to disclose
information about their current level of exposure (to both transition and physical climate
s well as to inform their future decisions
. Reporting to date is, however, inconsistent
of metrics, methodologies, and approaches developed
by commercial providers that contribute to
here is currently not enough evidence in order to conclude whether climate
risk assessments result in increased climate action and alignment with the goals of the Paris
As developed in Section 15.6.3, the insufficient level of ambition and coherence of public policies at
onal and international level remains the root cause of the still significant misalignment of investment
and financing compared to pathways compatible with the Paris Agreement temperature goal
. Such lack of coherence includes low pricing of
carbon and of environmental externalities more
generally, as well as misaligned policies in non
climate policy areas such as fiscal, trade, industrial and
The most documented policy misalignment relates to the remaining very large scale of public direct and
indirect financial support for fossil fuel
n and consumption in many parts of the world
(Bast et al. 2015; Coady et al. 2017; Climate Transparency 2020)
